channel.title: Dealing with a community server
channel.description:
There has been a ton of talk on doing a community server lately (way more than usual) and, despite my own cynicism, I still love the idea. Rather than going on with members who don't care about anything but the features, I want to query MoparScape's elite on what they think should be done in the realm of a community server.
As far as the discussion is concerned, it's worth noting that most people want to start a new framework entirely. This is both impractical and technically beyond the scope of a community server. A community server focuses on the community collaborating in content development (at least, that's specifically what I'm asking). We already have a server base to use--Osiris. If you feel that a new framework is warranted and perhaps an even better project than just doing content, feel free to state your case. I like the idea of promoting Osiris more, though.
What does everyone think about getting some stuff stirred up for a community server? How would you manage it?

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini

@sinisoul wrote:

Well, besides that theres a few changes I’d like to see happen like cleaning up all the additions to the source. Just general rebasing.

item.description:
@lawl wrote:

I haven’t read the thread but @Davidi2, I don’t like the hardcoding of ID’s, wouldn’t it be nicer to have a database of symbols=>ids that you could query? Also, stuff like create_hatchets should really be entirely stored in a database.

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

Given how aggressive Jagex is in their swipes at any server that gains any considerably large user base, this is just asking for trouble. I have seen excellent servers (with horrible server base, but an incredible community), with very careful individuals running in the background get shut down by Jagex.

Read full topic

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:134, topic:443579”]I don’t think I’m exaggerating, considering the community and how hard it is for them to learn good java practices as it is. There’s a difference between learning ruby and then learning good ruby practice that you would deem acceptable and good design too[/quote]It will probably weed out all the less valuable input from crappy developers. A good developer should be able to adapt to new languages much easier than someone just getting into the game.

Read full topic

I know you guys said that the people who can contribute the most can easily learn Ruby, but I still don’t think you’re going to get the community help required to make this a success. I didn’t bother reading through 3 pages of input from you guys, but rather just giving my opinion.

Read full topic

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:153, topic:443579”]Ruby has too many shortcuts tbh. =\ How long did it take you guys to become proficient?[/quote]I’m going to assume you were talking to Graham, but for me I’ve spent around 5-6 hours on it and I think I know the basics of the language

Also, thoughts on moving this to a public section or creating a new topic for it? Maybe sticking? I just don’t want this to fizzle out like every other community project topic considering we have a good base to go on and content development is pretty much ready to move forward. Only seeing 2-3 people replying is not very motivating (to clarify, I mean the project as in the idea, maybe the plugins, not the whole source yet)

Read full topic

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

return false
      end

You could just put ‘false’, you don’t need to put return at the end of a method if there aren’t any other blocks of code past that point.

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

http://pastie.org/private/kwqum9xffu7a5xasdzzy2g

Here’s mining

The main differences are that there’s no log_amt for the Rock object (because 99% of them only give 1, and the other ones are veins and the rune ess mine, so I figure I can create a different class for those when I add them), and that there’s no stump(depleted)_id for the RockType class. The reasoning behind this is that there’s like 50 different ids for each ore that look different. So I have a new method called find_depleted_id that will populate a hash for the depleted ids for each rock…

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

@ Conventions - Yea I knew about most of those, still adapting from java (only being really learning ruby for a few hours on 2 or 3 days), especially when it comes to the parenthesis

@ object.id rather than object.getId - the reason I did that was because I wasnt sure how jruby interacted with private variables in a class, but if that works I’ll use that instead
@ 247-270 - I guess I could have something like

TREE_TYPE_IDENTIFIERS = {NORMAL_TREES => :normal, ACHEY_TREES => :achey ... etc}

def groundObjectAdded(object)
  TREE_TYPE_IDENTIFIERS.each do |ids, identifier|
  if ids.include?object.id
    TREES[object.position] = Tree.new(object, TREE_TYPES[identifier])
    break
  end
end

Would that work?

EDIT - Or even just modify the TREE_TYPES hash to be <IDS_ARRAY, TreeType> instead of <:ident, TreeType>, ill rewrite

EDIT 2 - Done
http://pastie.org/private/bfxk9qcpmfumqr69lws5q
Better?

Read full topic

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

btw JRuby will allow you to use Ruby naming conventions to call methods which are named with Java naming conventions. E.g.:

if @player.getInventory().freeSlots() < 1
  @player.sendMessage("Your inventory is too full to hold any more logs.")
  stop()
  return
end

can actually be written as:

if @player.inventory.free_slots < 1
  @player.send_message "Your inventory is too full to hold any more logs."
  stop
  return
end

and an example of setting a variable:

@object.setId(@original_id)

this can be written as:

@object.id = @original_id

Also in TreeType/Hatchet you are using attr_accessor, I suspect you intend for these classes to be immutable, in which case you can use attr_reader instead. Similarly in Tree, I haven’t checked but I suspect tree_type and object are probably read-only, so you could use attr_reader there too.

You’ve also got brackets in lots of places where Ruby lets you drop them and it would be convention to leave them off e.g.

def create_tree_types()

could be

def create_tree_types

You can also leave them off on a lot of your method calls too, but that’s probably more debatable than dropping them from zero-arg function definitions.

Convention for blocks is to use do/end for multiple lines, and braces for a single line, so e.g.:

HATCHETS.each { |id, hatchet|
  next if(!best_hatchet.nil? && HATCHETS[id].speed < best_hatchet.speed)
  (best_hatchet = hatchet) if (@player.getInventory.slotOf(id) > -1 && get_wc_lvl() >= hatchet.level)
}

would generally be written like so (also removing brackets you don’t need, using Ruby-style naming, using contains instead of slotOf and using hatchet instead of HATCHETS[id]: )

HATCHETS.each do |id, hatchet|
  next if !best_hatchet.nil? && hatchet.speed < best_hatchet.speed
  best_hatchet = hatchet if @player.inventory.contains(id) && get_wc_level >= hatchet.level
end

Lines 247-270 are pretty bad, is there a way you can do this avoiding you having to repeat code for each tree type?

Read full topic

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:145, topic:443579”]Don’t know enough about ruby to make a judgement call, but does that implement absolutely everything in just 301 lines?[/quote]yea, well there’s also a bit in the bootstrap script for this: Bootstrap.bind_object_option

Which is about 10 lines, but yea thats all

Also worth pointing out I add a lot of unneeded blank lines after if-end statements, and have about 30 lines of comments

But to be fair, the woodcutting I wrote in Java for prs06 is 180 lines, or around 200 if you count the switch statements in the ObjectOption handlers

Stop focusing on the lowest common denominator imo. The development side of it should be developed with developers in mind, not non-programmers. Non-programmers then have two choices: a) Stick with publicly released plugins b) Learn to program.

item.title: Dealing with a community server
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

Davidi2:

I was merely pointing out that the majority of the community will be somewhat experienced with the concepts of Java

To be honest, the majority of the community is (sadly) only familiar with copying and pasting from tutorials. Anyone who does actually know how to program Java shouldn’t have many problems picking up a scripting language, whether it’s Ruby or something else.

btw sini: the LICENSE file from scapeemu seems to have not been included in the server you released that is based on it, I’d appreciate it if you could include it in the download (technically you have to do so although I’m not going to be strict about it).

Read full topic
